title: Is the argument “a is b” but “b is not a” valid? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hoooooooold on, two steps back from these other answers for a second. TL;DR: You question is posed poorly. Your phrasing here is…confusing. You ask if the “argument” is valid, but you haven’t made an argument here. You have two separate propositions. There’s no therefor, and there’s no conclusion. If you’re asking if both of these two things can be true, then we need to ask the next important question: In which systems of logic can these two statements be true? That all comes down to, if you’ll excuse my quoting a president, what your definition of “is” is. If you mean “a = b” and “b =\= a”, then we’re looking at most forms of mathematics or some kind of symbolic logic, and if that equals sign implies reflectivity, then those statements cannot both be true. Other answers have added other things to this: a is a member of b, but b is not a member of a, or “All squares are rectangles, but not all rectangles are squares.” In the first case, this chooses a definition of ‘is’ to bring up sets. In the second, though, you’re changing the definitions of ‘a’ and ‘b’. “All squares are rectangles.”a = All Squaresb = Rectangles “All rectangles are not squares.”a = Squaresb = All Rectangles And that makes this questionable as well. So in order to tell you whether both of those exist, we would need to know what system of logic you’re trying to follow, your definitions of your variables (a, b, etc) and your definition of ‘is’. So to sum up my final answer: Maybe, but probably not.

It depends on what a and b are. If a is b then b must be a at least sometimes. when a is a subset of b for example Texas is a state but not all states are Texas or all Fords are cars but not all cars are Fords. Now if you are saying a is b but b is never a then you have a contradiction which invalidates things.
